ARTS-6989.courseDescription: are advanced courses on specialized topics in French language. Subjects to be treated will be announced each year by the Department.

ARTS-6988.courseDescription: is an introduction to principles and methods of translation from French to English and English to French. Comparative stylistics of French and English.

ARTS-6095.PR: FREN 1501 with a grade of at least 60% or by permission of the Head of the Department. Students may not register concurrently for more than one of FREN 1500 , 1501 and 1502 except with the permission of the Head of the Department. Very well-prepared students may apply to the Department for permission to enter 1502 directly.
ARTS-6095.courseDescription: is one of three consecutive credit courses in French language at the first-year university level, offering a complete overview of basic oral and written French.
ARTS-6095.LH: two additional hours of language laboratory work or conversation class, or both

ARTS-6093.PR: High School FREN 3200 or permission of the Head of the Department. Ex-immersion students should consult the Head of the Department before registering for this course. Students may not register concurrently for more than one of FREN 1500 , 1501 and 1502 except with the permission of the Head of the Department.
ARTS-6093.courseDescription: is one of three consecutive credit courses in French language at the first-year university level, offering a complete overview of basic oral and written French. New students may choose to register initially in FREN
ARTS-6093.LH: two additional hours of language laboratory work or conversation class, or both

ARTS-6091.PR: students may not register concurrently for more than one of FREN 1500, 1501 and 1502 except with the permission of the Head of the Department.
ARTS-6091.courseDescription: is a course for beginners and for students whose background in French is very weak. Students with a strong background in high-school French should bypass 1500 and begin their University study with
ARTS-6091.LH: two additional hours of language laboratory work or conversation class, or both
ARTS-6091.CR: the former FREN 1010 or the former FREN 1011
ARTS-6091.UL: permission to register for this course will not be given to students who have completed Français 3202 (High School French immersion)

ARTS-6981.PR: admission to the Canadian Third Year Program in Nice and French 3507
ARTS-6981.courseDescription: is a required course of Session II of the

ARTS-6980.PR: admission to the Canadian Third Year Program in Nice and 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level, or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6980.courseDescription: is a required course of Session I of the

ARTS-6983.PR: 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6983.courseDescription: is an introduction to the culture of Quebec. Practice in oral and written French.

ARTS-6982.PR: 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6982.courseDescription: is an introduction to the culture of France. Practice in oral and written French.

ARTS-6985.PR: 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6985.courseDescription: studies the role, the diversity of the French language, its status and challenges in the French-speaking world outside France and Canada.

ARTS-6984.PR: 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6984.courseDescription: is an introduction to the culture of French-speaking regions of Canada other than Quebec. Practice in oral and written French.

ARTS-6987.courseDescription: is an intensive review of the stylistics of written French, including levels of expression and composition of texts with a Francophone audience in mind (correspondence, reports, etc.). Advanced oral practice.

ARTS-6986.PR: 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6986.courseDescription: examines a cultural aspect of the Francophone world through an interdisciplinary approach in order to better understand the dynamics at work.

ARTS-6127.PR: SPAN 2001 or equivalent but may vary with each new course
ARTS-6127.courseDescription: will have the particulars available on the Departmental website.
ARTS-6127.CO: SPAN 2001 or equivalent but may vary with each new course
ARTS-6127.CR: currently not applicable but may vary with each new course

ARTS-6118.PR: SPAN 2001 or equivalent, or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6118.courseDescription: explores Latin-American culture and civilization from pre-Columbian times to the present. Particular attention will be paid to issues of colonization, identity and to the background of the various independence and revolutionary movements in the region.

ARTS-6119.PR: SPAN 2001 or equivalent, or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6119.courseDescription: is a survey course on the development of Latin-American literature from pre-Columbian times to the Modernism movement.

ARTS-6134.courseDescription: is a study of the characteristics of theatre, its literary and performative aspects, and its relationship to history, culture and society.
ARTS-6134.CO: Spanish 2001 and any 3000-level Spanish course or equivalent, or permission of the Head of the Department

ARTS-6135.courseDescription: is an exploration of 20th century Latin-American poetry and the complex relationship between its social and poetic components. Among the topics to be studied are subjectivity, authority and gender. The course includes Latino-Canadian poets.
ARTS-6135.CO: Spanish 2001 and any 3000-level Spanish course or equivalent, or permission of the Head of the Department

ARTS-6126.PR: SPAN 2001 or equivalent but may vary with each new course
ARTS-6126.courseDescription: will have the particulars available on the Departmental website.
ARTS-6126.CO: SPAN 2001 or equivalent but may vary with each new course
ARTS-6126.CR: currently not applicable but may vary with each new course

ARTS-6113.courseDescription: is a general introduction to the historical and cultural background and development of sixteenth and seventeenth century Spanish prose literature through study of Lazarillo de Tormes, Don Quijote and El Buscón. Special emphasis is given to the picaresque novel and on the originality of Cervantes and the creation of the first truly "modern" novel.
ARTS-6113.courseTitle: Spanish Literature of the Golden Age

ARTS-6110.courseTitle: Spanish Literature of the 18th and 19th Century I

ARTS-6116.PR: SPAN 2001 or equivalent, or permission of the Head of the Department.
ARTS-6116.courseDescription: is a study of selected (subtitled) films by representative film-makers from the Hispanic world. Emphasis will be placed on the cultural and social issues explored in the films and the historical context in which they emerge.
ARTS-6116.UL: not acceptable towards the second language requirement for the completion of the Bachelor of Arts degree

ARTS-6114.courseDescription: is a general survey of Spanish literary works of the twentieth century, with a detailed study of representative authors.

ARTS-6974.PR: 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6974.courseDescription: pays particular attention to the literatures of French Canada and France.
ARTS-6974.courseTitle: An Introduction to Prose Literature in French

ARTS-6975.PR: 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6975.courseDescription: pays particular attention to the literatures of French Canada and France.
ARTS-6975.courseTitle: An Introduction to Drama in French

ARTS-6976.PR: 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6976.courseDescription: pays particular attention to the literatures of French Canada and France.
ARTS-6976.courseTitle: An Introduction to Poetry in French

ARTS-6977.PR: 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6977.courseDescription: is the study of a particular theme or of interrelated themes in selected French-language texts.

ARTS-6958.courseDescription: is a practical introduction to French phonetics, including the International Phonetic Alphabet and phonetic transcription as well as corrective phonetics.
ARTS-6958.OR: may be offered in accelerated format outside the regular semester or session timeframe when being delivered as part of the Frecker Summer Program

ARTS-6959.courseDescription: will explore reading strategies in a variety of narrative and descriptive readings in French. This course will normally be taught in French.

ARTS-6956.PR: primarily intended for students who completed immersion programs or with permission of the Head of the Department. FREN 2159 and 2160 are courses designed for former French immersion students as well as others with exceptional backgrounds in French, and are intended as an alternative to the 1500 , 1501 , 1502 , 2100 , 2101 sequence.
ARTS-6956.courseDescription: is primarily intended to build on the language skills acquired by students in immersion programs. Development of reading, writing, listening and speaking ability through practical oral and written exercises. Other qualified students may register with the permission of the Head of Department.
ARTS-6956.courseTitle: Advanced French for First-year Students I
ARTS-6956.UL: this course does not satisfy the requirements of the Major and Minor programs in French

ARTS-6957.PR: FREN 2159 and 2160 are courses designed for former French immersion students as well as others with exceptional backgrounds in French, and are intended as an alternative to the 1500 , 1501 , 1502 , 2100 , 2101 sequence.
ARTS-6957.courseDescription: is an intensive review of French grammar with oral and written practice. Particular attention will be paid to ensuring precision in language use in both oral and written forms and to eradicating anglicisms.
ARTS-6957.courseTitle: Advanced French for First-year Students II
ARTS-6957.UL: this course does not satisfy the requirements of the Major and Minor programs in French

ARTS-6955.courseDescription: is further work in composition, grammar and oral skills.

ARTS-6978.PR: 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6978.courseDescription: is the study of one or more literary periods through selected French-language texts.

ARTS-6979.PR: 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6979.courseDescription: is a survey course designed to acquaint students with the major productions and trends in French cinema. The course is taught in French, and films screened will not necessarily have English subtitles. It is therefore recommended that students have a good aural comprehension of French.

ARTS-6133.courseDescription: will examine the genesis and development of this groundbreaking movement from its beginnings in 1885 to its transformation into the avant-garde movement in the first decades of the 20th Century.
ARTS-6133.CO: Spanish 2001 and any 3000-level Spanish course or equivalent, or permission of the Head of the Department

ARTS-6121.PR: SPAN 2001 or equivalent, or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6121.courseDescription: is a survey course on general characteristics and history of the short story. Emphasis will be placed on close reading of stories from different geographical areas, such as Mexico, Cuba, Argentina, Colombia, and the U.S.

ARTS-7035.PR: FREN 1502 with a grade of at least 60%
ARTS-7035.courseDescription: is a course on composition, grammar and practice in oral skills.

ARTS-7669.PR: SPAN 2000 and 2005 , or equivalent, or permission from the Head of the Department

ARTS-7668.PR: SPAN 1001 , or equivalent, or permission from the Head of the Department
ARTS-7668.courseDescription: is an intermediate course that focuses on communication skills in Spanish (listening, speaking, reading and writing) as well as on the acquisition of intercultural competence to use Spanish in business-oriented situations. This course is open to native or near-native speakers.

ARTS-6998.PR: two of: FREN 3500 , 3501 , 3502 , 3503 , 3504 , 3506 , 3507 , 3508 or one course in that series with a grade of 80% or above
ARTS-6998.courseDescription: is a study of a genre from French-language literature of different periods to be chosen among other literary and popular genres such as: essay, tract, manifesto; memoirs, diary, autobiography; personal writing, fantasy, best sellers, detective novel, spy novel, science fiction, etc.

ARTS-6992.courseDescription: deals with the identity of French Newfoundlanders. It will examine the historical context that lead to the emergence of a distinct identity, contacts between Newfoundland and France and the origin of francophone communities on the West coast. The traditional ways of life, folklore and traditions of these communities and their evolutions during the 20th century will also be studied.

ARTS-6120.PR: SPAN 2001 or equivalent, or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6120.courseDescription: is a survey of major trends in Latin-American literature since Modernismo and analysis of selected works of prose, poetry and drama.

ARTS-6996.PR: two of: FREN 3500 , 3501 , 3502 , 3503 , 3504 , 3506 , 3507 , 3508 or one course in that series with a grade of 80% or above
ARTS-6996.courseDescription: is French literary history through the study of a movement or trend in literature since realism: realism, naturalism, symbolism, surrealism, existentialism, feminism, postmodernism, the absurd, nouveau roman, roman du terroir, etc.

ARTS-6997.PR: two of: FREN 3500 , 3501 , 3502 , 3503 , 3504 , 3506 , 3507 , 3508 or one course in that series with a grade of 80% or above
ARTS-6997.courseDescription: is a study of a genre from French-literature of different periods to be chosen among the traditional or canonical forms (poetry, narrative fiction, theatre): poem, epic, novel, short story, novella tragedy, comedy, drama.

ARTS-6995.PR: two of: FREN 3500 , 3501 , 3502 , 3503 , 3504 , 3506 , 3507 , 3508 or one course in that series with a grade of 80% or above
ARTS-6995.courseDescription: is French literary history through the study of a movement or trend in literature up to romanticism: courtoisie, libertinage, libre pensée (free thought), the baroque, humanism, classicism, romanticism, etc.

ARTS-6109.courseDescription: is a continuation of Intermediate Spanish I.

ARTS-6108.courseDescription: is a continuation of the basic grammar, reading, and oral Spanish completed in the elementary program.

ARTS-6141.PR: SPAN 1001 or permission of the Head of the Department. Offered only in the context of a study-abroad program in a Spanish speaking country.
ARTS-6141.courseDescription: will focus on hispanic literary and cultural studies at the intermediate level and in an intensive immersion setting.
ARTS-6141.courseTitle: Intermediate Hispanic Cultural and Literary Studies

ARTS-6140.PR: SPAN 1001 or permission of the Head of the Department. Offered only in the context of a study-abroad program in a Spanish speaking country.
ARTS-6140.courseDescription: will emphasize the development of aural comprehension and oral expression in Spanish in an intensive immersion setting. The course will also include work on written expression and comprehension.

ARTS-6143.PR: SPAN 2001 or permission of the Head of the Department. Offered only in the context of a study-abroad program in a Spanish speaking country.
ARTS-6143.courseTitle: Advanced Hispanic Cultural and Literary Studies

ARTS-6142.PR: SPAN 2001 or permission of the Head of the Department. Offered only in the context of a study-abroad program in a Spanish speaking country.

ARTS-6101.courseDescription: is a continuation of Elementary Italian I.

ARTS-6100.courseDescription: is for beginners in Italian. Introduction to the fundamentals of Italian grammar, with particular attention to the acquisition of basic skills in oral and written communication.

ARTS-6125.courseDescription: is a continuation of Advanced Spanish I.

ARTS-6124.courseDescription: covers oral Spanish, composition and reading of contemporary literary materials; phonetics.

ARTS-6123.courseDescription: is a study of representative works of Spanish-American literature of the twentieth century.

ARTS-6122.courseDescription: is a study of representative works of Latin-American literature of the twentieth century.

ARTS-6107.courseDescription: is a continuation of Elementary Spanish I.

ARTS-6106.courseDescription: is an introductory course, grammar, reading and oral Spanish.

ARTS-6963.courseDescription: examines role and function of the parts of speech in French; semantic enrichment (synonymy, polysemy); tropes and figures of speech. Grammatical and stylistic textual analysis with special emphasis on these phenomena. Vocabulary enrichment.

ARTS-6962.PR: FREN 2101 and 9 additional credit hours in French at the second-year level, or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6962.courseDescription: is a revision of the French noun and verb systems (morphology, number, gender, tense, aspect, mood, voice). Grammatical and stylistic textual analysis with special emphasis on the use of verbs in French. Vocabulary enrichment.

ARTS-6961.PR: FREN 1502 or equivalent. Students who have obtained less than 70% in 1051 are, however, advised to complete FREN 2100 before attempting this course.
ARTS-6961.courseDescription: places emphasis on oral comprehension and expression.
ARTS-6961.OR: may be offered in accelerated format outside the regular semester or session timeframe when being delivered as part of the Frecker Summer Program

ARTS-6960.courseDescription: will explore reading strategies in a variety of readings in FREN intended to inform or persuade. This course will normally be taught in French.

ARTS-6967.PR: 15 credit hours in French and/or Linguistics at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department; Classics 1120 is strongly recommended

ARTS-6966.PR: 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6966.courseDescription: is convincing and arguing in French. The course will be structured by rhetoric: memory, invention, disposition, elocution, diction. Various oral exercises.
ARTS-6966.OR: two and a half hours of instruction plus one 50-minute period of conversation class per week

ARTS-6965.PR: admission to the Canadian Third Year Program in Nice and French 3102 , or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6965.courseDescription: is a required course of Session II of the Canadian Third Year Program in Nice. The content of this course will be the continuation of the language course offered during the previous semester.

ARTS-6964.PR: admission to the Canadian Third Year Program in Nice , 15 credit hours in French at the 2000 level, or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6964.courseDescription: is a required course of Session I of the Canadian Third Year Program in Nice. The content of this course will be the equivalent of a language course at the third year level.

ARTS-6969.PR: 15 credit hours in French and/or Linguistics at the 2000 level or permission of the instructor
ARTS-6969.courseTitle: Introduction to General Linguistics: Aspects of French Linguistic Theory

ARTS-6968.PR: 15 credit hours in French and/or Linguistics at the 2000 level or permission of the Head of the Department

ARTS-6132.PR: Spanish 2001 and any 3000-level Spanish course or equivalent, or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6132.courseDescription: examines a cross-section of literary currents in 20th century Latin-American narrative prose fiction. The complex interplay of myth and reality is examined in, for example, the novel of the revolution, La novela de la tierra, La novela de dictador, La novela femenina and La novela testimonial.

ARTS-7004.PR: completion of FREN 4900 with a minimum grade of 70%
ARTS-7004.courseDescription: under the direction of their assigned supervisors, students will complete the writing of their honours essay. Students are expected to meet regularly with their supervisors.

ARTS-7003.PR: admission to the honours program in French and permission of the Head of Department
ARTS-7003.courseDescription: under the direction of their assigned supervisors, students will select an honours essay topic, prepare a research proposal, and submit a draft of at least one section of the honours essay. Students are expected to meet regularly with their supervisors.

ARTS-7002.PR: two of: FREN 3500 , 3501 , 3502 , 3503 , 3504 , 3506 , 3507 , 3508 or one course in that series with a grade of 80% or above
ARTS-7002.courseDescription: are advanced courses on specialized topics in literature written in French. Subjects to be treated will be announced each year by the Department.

ARTS-7000.PR: FREN 3100 , 3101 and one other third-year French course
ARTS-7000.courseDescription: are advanced courses on specialized topics in Francophone culture. Subjects to be treated will be announced each year by the Department.
